messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 45 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Learning from Łukasiewicz and Meredith: Investigations into Proof Structures (Extended Version)

Paper Abstract: Abstract The material presented in this paper contributes to establishing a basis deemed essential for substantial progress in Automated Deduction. It identifies and studies global features in selected problems and their proofs which offer the potential of guiding proof search in a more direct way. The studied problems are of the wide-spread form of “axiom(s) and rule(s) imply goal(s)”. The features include the well-known concept of lemmas. For their elaboration both human and automated proofs of selected theorems are taken into a close comparative consideration. The study at the same time accounts for a coherent and comprehensive formal reconstruction of historical work by Łukasiewicz, Meredith and others. First experiments resulting from the study indicate novel ways of lemma generation to supplement automated first-order provers of various families, strengthening in particular their ability to find short proofs.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 45 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 45"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Automated Theorem Proving",
        "Deduction: Automated Logic",
        "From Schütte’s formal systems to modern automated deduction",
        "A simplified form of condensed detachment",
        "First order proof problems extracted from an article in the Mizar mathematical library",
        "Notations for rewriting",
        "Variations on the common subexpression problem",
        "Relative Complexities of First Order Calculi",
        "Properties of substitutions and unification",
        "Machine learning guidance for connection tableaux",
        "Missing proofs found",
        "Analytic variations on the common subexpression problem",
        "Algorithmic introduction of quantified cuts",
        "Principal type-schemes and condensed detachment",
        "Tableaux and related methods",
        "ENIGMA Anonymous: Symbol-independent inference guiding machine (system description)",
        "Condensed detachment as a rule of inference",
        "Calculi of pure strict implication",
        "SETHEO: A high-performance theorem prover",
        "Grammar-based tree compression",
        "The shortest axiom of the implicational calculus of propositions",
        "Selected Works",
        "Untersuchungen über den Aussagenkalkül",
        "Experiments with ROO, a parallel automated deduction system",
        "Experiments in automated deduction with condensed detachment",
        "Notes on the axiomatics of the propositional calculus",
        "In memoriam: Carew Arthur Meredith (1904–1976)",
        "The on-line encyclopedia of integer sequences",
        "Restricting backtracking in connection calculi",
        "System description: E-KRHyper",
        "Single axioms in the implicational propositional calculus",
        "Logicians at play; or Syll, Simp and Hilbert",
        "Formal Logic",
        "Faster, higher, stronger: E 2.3",
        "DELTA – A bottom-up preprocessor for top-down theorem provers",
        "A Prolog technology theorem prover: implementation by an extended Prolog compiler",
        "A legacy recalled and a tradition continued",
        "Single axioms and axiom-pairs for the implicational fragments of R, R-Mingle, and some related systems",
        "Vampire, online: https://vprover.github.io/, accessed Feb 5, 2021",
        "Finding shortest proofs: An application of linked inference rules",
        "The PIE system for proving, interpolating and eliminating",
        "Facets of the PIE environment for proving, interpolating and eliminating on the basis of first-order logic",
        "Investigations into proof structures",
        "Atomic cut introduction by resolution: Proof structuring and compression",
        "Automated reasoning contributes to mathematics and logic"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 45 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Learning from Łukasiewicz and Meredith: Investigations into Proof Structures (Extended Version), providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
